are two important processes that classically play a critical role in determining the energy efficiency and cycle life. However, both reactions exhibit intrinsically sluggish kinetics because they naturally occur at multiphase interfaces, proceeding through multistep electron transfer pathways.[2] Noble metals and their alloys have been recognized as the most efficient oxygen electrocatalysts; however, the prohibitive cost, rare availability, and poor stability severely limit their application and commercialization.[3] Moreover, the monofunctionality of these noble metals, e.g., Pt capable of catalysing ORR only while Ru/Ir-based materials as OER catalysts, results in the fact that they cannot simultaneously catalyse the two half reactions with low overpotentials, which is extremely required for the construction of regenerative and rechargeable electrochemical systems. Therefore, exploitation of highly active, durable, and bifunctional electrocatalysts from earth-abundant elements is urgently needed.[4]
Transition-metal compounds (TMCs) represent a class of promising candidates due to their natural advantages of low price, abundant resources, and envi-
ronmental friendliness.[5] Compared to binary TMCs, ternary TMCs have received extensive interest because of the incorporation of a secondary metallic redox site and increased structural stability.[6] Furthermore, a number of recent studies reports that hybrid electrocatalysts composed of bimetallic TMCs and heteroatom-doped carbonaceous materials exhibit enhanced bifunctional ORR/OER activity owing to fast interfacial electron transfer and the synergistic effect originating from the chemical coupling between bimetallic atoms and N-doped carbon.[6e–h] However, restricted by the doping strategy and maintenance of the sp2 carbon framework in traditional carbonaceous supports (e.g., graphene and carbon nanotubes (CNTs)), it is rather difficult to selectively control the formation of favorable N configurations (e.g., pyridinic N according to previous observations[6g,7]) and the concentration of total nitrogen content is normally limited in the range of 4–6 atom %,[5a,6g,h,8] which constrains the activation of potential bimetallic sites at the heterostructures and hinders the further activity enhancement to a satisfactory
Hybrid materials composed of transition-metal compounds and nitrogendoped carbonaceous supports are promising electrocatalysts for various electrochemical energy conversion devices, whose activity enhancements can be attributed to the synergistic effect between metallic sites and N dopants. While the functionality of single-metal catalysts is relatively well-understood, the mechanism and synergy of bimetallic systems are less explored. Herein, the design and fabrication of an integrated flexible electrode based on NiCo2S4/graphitic carbon nitride/carbon nanotube (NiCo2S4@g-C3N4-CNT) are reported. Comparative studies evidence the electronic transfer from bimetallic Ni/Co active sites to abundant pyridinic-N in underlying g-C3N4 and the synergistic effect with coupled conductive CNTs for promoting reversible oxygen electrocatalysis. Theoretical calculations demonstrate the unique coactivation of bimetallic Ni/Co atoms by pyridinic-N species (a Ni, Co–N2 moiety), which simultaneously downshifts their d-band center positions and benefits the adsorption/desorption features of oxygen intermediates, accelerating the reaction kinetics. The optimized NiCo2S4@g-C3N4-CNT hybrid manifests outstanding bifunctional performance for catalyzing oxygen reduction/ evolution reactions, highly efficient for realistic zinc–air batteries featuring low overpotential, high efficiency, and long durability, superior to those of physical mixed counterparts and state-of-the-art noble metal catalysts. The identified bimetallic coactivation mechanism will shed light on the rational design and interfacial engineering of hybrid nanomaterials for diverse applications.

sections.heading: Hybrid Materials
sections.text:
Concerns originating from energy and environmental issues have promoted extensive research worldwide on sustainable energy conversion and storage technologies, including fuel cells, metal–air batteries, water electrolysers, etc.[1] Oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) and oxygen evolution reaction (OER)

© 2019 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim1808281 (2 of 10)
level. More importantly, notwithstanding significant progress in experiments, a deeper understanding of the fundamental mechanisms of catalytically bimetallic systems for hybrid electrocatalysts is still ambiguous. Although the coordination interaction between monometallic atom and high-affinity N dopants in the carbon matrix (i.e., M–N/C active structure, M = Fe, Co, Ni, etc.) is recognized to play a key role in facilitating the ORR/ OER processes,[9] less exploration has been made to clarify the mechanism and synergy of bimetallic sites in enhancing the catalytic activities of TMCs/N-doped carbon composites. In other words, it still remains unclear how the bimetallic atoms would cooperate with underlying bonded nitrogen dopants at the hybrid nanointerfaces to synergistically catalyse the reversible oxygen electrocatalysis.
Among various N-doped carbon substances, graphitic carbon nitride (g-C3N4) attracts our attention because of its unique merits of extremely high nitrogen content (≈57 atom%), graphene-like structure, and large surface area.[10] Moreover, since the most recent studies have demonstrated the beneficial effect of pyridinic N-metal bonds in accelerating the redox ORR/ OER,[6g,7] the homogeneously dispersed and abundant pyridinelike nitrogen ligands in g-C3N4 are expected to trap and activate more bimetallic species when anchoring ternary TMCs on 2D g-C3N4 matrix, thus enabling hybrid materials with an increased number of catalytically active sites for electrocatalysis. This smart hybrid model also provides opportunities to understand the synergistic effect between bimetallic active sites and the coordinated N species for oxygen electrocatalysis. Although the poor electrical conductivity is still a major obstacle to the use of g-C3N4 as electrocatalysts, it has already been conquered by covalent coupling with conductive materials.[11] Hence, in the context of developing inexpensive and efficient hybrid oxygen electrocatalysts, supporting bimetallic TMCs on N-rich g-C3N4 reinforced by the construction of an effective electron transfer network deserves particular interest from both fundamental and technological fields.
In this work, a novel NiCo2S4 nanocrystal/g-C3N4 nanosheet/ CNT hybrid material (denoted as NiCo2S4@g-C3N4-CNT) was synthesized and investigated as a free-standing and flexible film electrode for promoting ORR/OER electrocatalysis and real Zn– air batteries (ZABs). The proposed synthetic strategy includes two-step hydrothermal approaches followed by a vacuum filtration process. Comparative experimental studies reveal the electronic interactions between bimetallic Ni/Co active sites and abundant pyridinic-N species in underlying g-C3N4 and the synergistic effect with coupled conductive CNTs for promoting reversible oxygen electrocatalysis. In particular, unlike the traditional M–N–C structure in single metal catalysts, theoretical computations demonstrate that the bimetallic Ni/Co sites in NiCo2S4 are coactivated by connecting to two pyridinic-N atoms in the underlying g-C3N4 (a Ni, Co–N2 moiety), which simultaneously downshifts their d-band center positions and facilitates the adsorption/desorption features of oxygen intermediates, accelerating the ORR/OER kinetics. Meanwhile, the integration of conductive CNTs provides a porous 3D network for efficient interfacial mass and charge transfer. Consequently, NiCo2S4@g-C3N4-CNT hybrid manifests outstanding catalytic activity and stability towards bifunctional ORR and OER in alkaline electrolyte, surpassing many of the reported TMC
electrocatalysts. When equipped in practical rechargeable liquid and solid-state flexible ZABs, it also endows them with small discharge/charge voltages, high energy efficiencies, and long operation lives that are superior to those of counterparts and even noble metal catalyst of Pt/C and RuO2.
Figure 1a schematically illustrates the preparation procedures of the free-standing NiCo2S4@g-C3N4-CNT composite film. First, NiCo2S4 nanoparticles were in situ grown on g-C3N4 nanosheets through a simple hydrothermal method, designated as NiCo2S4@g-C3N4. Then, the NiCo2S4@g-C3N4 hybrid and mildly oxidized CNTs were ultrasonically dispersed in a water/isopropanol mixed solvent to obtain NiCo2S4@g-C3N4CNT precursor solution through a second hydrothermal treatment. A flexible NiCo2S4@g-C3N4-CNT film electrode was finally obtained by a vacuum filtration process. The successful formation of the three components in NiCo2S4@g-C3N4-CNT hybrid was revealed by X-ray diffraction (XRD) and Raman spectra (Figure S1, Supporting Information). Figure 1b shows a transmission electron microscopy (TEM) image of bare g-C3N4 nanosheets, displaying a homogeneous membrane structure several micronmeters in size (Figure S2, Supporting Information). Atomic force microscopy (AFM) further confirms the ultrathin nanosheet morphology of g-C3N4 with the thickness of 3–4 nm (Figure 1c; Figure S3, Supporting Information). NiCo2S4 nanocrystals are homogeneously dispersed on g-C3N4 nanosheets in the NiCo2S4@g-C3N4 hybrid without obvious detachment and aggregation (Figure 1d). The membrane structure of g-C3N4 is essentially retained and the average particle size of supported NiCo2S4 nanoparticles is ≈22 nm (Figure S4, Supporting Information). TEM image of the NiCo2S4@g-C3N4CNT hybrid shows the coexistence of closely interconnected NiCo2S4@g-C3N4 with conductive CNTs (Figure 1e). Notably, the 1D CNTs wrap on the surface of NiCo2S4@g-C3N4 layer, forming a 3D porous architecture (Figure S5, Supporting Information). Inset in panel e shows a digital image of the flexible NiCo2S4@g-C3N4-CNT film, implying promising potential of the prepared hybrids to be directly applied as integrated electrodes for flexible energy conversion devices. Elemental mapping further demonstrates the homogeneous dispersion of various elements, including C, N, Ni, Co, and S (Figure S6, Supporting Information). In the high-resolution TEM (HRTEM, Figure 1f) and selected area electron diffraction (SAED, Figure S7, Supporting Information), the observed lattice fringes with neighboring interlayer distances of 0.26 and 0.29 nm are respectively assigned to the (222) and (311) planes of spinel NiCo2S4. These observations collectively demonstrate the successful synthesis of NiCo2S4@g-C3N4-CNT nanocomposite through the proposed controllable stepwise strategy.
Brunner–Emmet–Teller (BET) surface area values of NiCo2S4@g-C3N4-CNT, g-C3N4, CNTs, and NiCo2S4@gC3N4 were characterized to be 154.66, 149.12, 113.47, and 125.07 m2 g–1 (Figure S8, Supporting Information), evidencing that NiCo2S4@g-C3N4-CNT is capable of providing large contact area and facilitating electrolyte infiltration during catalytic processes. The peak centered at ≈12 nm on the pore-size distribution curve verifies the presence of mesoporous structure in the fabricated free-standing film. The thickness of NiCo2S4@g-C3N4-CNT films can be tailored from 60 to 180 µm by simply changing the added amount of raw materials during

© 2019 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim1808281 (3 of 10)
the preparation process (Figure S9, Supporting Information). The electrical conductivity of the integrated electrode improves with increasing the electrode thickness and peaks at a maximized value of 150 µm owning to the appearance of obvious cracks at a thicker size of 180 µm (Figure S10, Supporting Information). The hybrid film possesses considerable mechanical properties. A maximum stretch stress of 30 MPa can be achieved at a strain percentage of 12% (Figure 1g), giving an average Young's modulus of 1.2 GPa. This is originated from intertwined framework constructed by CNTs and the NiCo2S4@g-C3N4 hybrid as well as the robust chemical coupling between them, which is confirmed by the inferior
Adv. Mater. 2019, 1808281
© 2019 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim1808281 (4 of 10)
mechanical behaviors of the benchmark samples without the second hydrothermal treatment (Figure S11, Supporting Information). The remarkable electrical conductivity and the synergistic effect in the NiCo2S4@g-C3N4-CNT hybrid are expected to substantially improve the electrocatalytic activity and stability.
X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was conducted to characterize the chemical composition, surface oxidation valence, and interfacial interaction. Mechanically mixed NiCo2S4/g-C3N4/CNT and NiCo2S4@g-C3N4/CNT counterparts were also tested for comparison (see the Supporting Information for synthetic details). XPS survey spectrum of NiCo2S4@g-C3N4-CNT confirms the presence of C, N, Ni, Co, and S (Figure S12, Supporting Information) and the determined stoichiometry is consistent with the data from energy-dispersive spectroscopy (EDS, Figure S13 and Table S1, Supporting Information). Figure 1h displays the Ni 2p spectra of three composites, which can be deconvoluted into six peaks of Ni2+ and Ni3+ species including two paired peaks and two shakeup satellites. The best-fitted six peaks of the Co 2p spectra in Figure 1i are assigned to the characteristic signals of Co2+ and Co3+ cations. Surprisingly, all the Ni 2p3/2 and Co 2p3/2 peaks in NiCo2S4@gC3N4/CNT and NiCo2S4@g-C3N4-CNT shift positively to higher binding energies in comparison to those of NiCo2S4/g-C3N4/ CNT. This movement implies that both Ni and Co species bind chemically with g-C3N4 in NiCo2S4@g-C3N4, resulting in partial electron migration from Ni and Co sites to high electronegative N sites.[6e,j,12] Particularly, the bimetallic Ni and Co ions are simultaneously interacted by the underlying N-rich g-C3N4 herein while monometallic site is coordinated with N atoms in traditional N-doped carbon supports.[6g] The strong electronic interaction is recognized to effectively optimize the adsorption/ activation/desorption behaviors of oxygen species on metallic active sites, consequently facilitating the overall reaction kinetics.[6i,12] Otherwise, the coupling effect between g-C3N4 and CNT is revealed by the deconvolution of the N 1s spectra for NiCo2S4@g-C3N4-CNT into four species (Figure 1j). The peak at 403.5 eV is ascribed to positively charged cyano groups and CN heterocycles in protonated g-C3N4.[13] The peak at 399.6 eV corresponds to the N(-C)3 in g-C3N4 or N atoms bonded with H in adsorbed H2O. The dominant peak at 398.2 eV can be assigned to sp2-bonded N atoms in triazine rings (CNC) and the obvious split peak at 397.5 eV is induced by the covalent interaction between CNTs and the N atoms in g-C3N4.[11b,14] This is further corroborated by the absence of the shoulder peak in physically mixed NiCo2S4/g-C3N4/CNT (Figure S12d, Supporting Information). XPS results demonstrate the electronic interaction between NiCo2S4 and g-C3N4 and covalent coupling between g-C3N4 and CNT in NiCo2S4@g-C3N4-CNT hybrid.
The electrocatalytic activities of synthesized catalysts were evaluated using a typical three-electrode configuration in alkaline media. The self-standing NiCo2S4@g-C3N4-CNT film can be directly employed as a working electrode for OER. NiCo2S4/ g-C3N4/CNT, NiCo2S4@g-C3N4/CNT, and RuO2 counterparts were also tested for comparison. As displayed in the OER linear sweep voltammograms (LSVs, Figure 2a), NiCo2S4@g-C3N4CNT requires an overpotential of 0.33 V to reach a anodic current density of 10 mA cm–2, which is lower than those of NiCo2S4@g-C3N4/CNT (0.37 V), NiCo2S4/g-C3N4/CNT (0.42 V) and can even compete with that of RuO2 catalyst (0.32 V). This
result proves the synergistic advantage of NiCo2S4, g-C3N4, and CNTs in the in situ fabricated NiCo2S4@g-C3N4-CNT for reducing the OER overpotential. The fitted Tafel curves reveal a much smaller slope for the NiCo2S4@g-C3N4-CNT (Figure 2b), indicating its favorable reaction kinetic. Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) analysis suggests a rapid charge transfer rate in NiCo2S4@g-C3N4-CNT (Figure S14, Supporting Information), which is also beneficial for the enhanced OER activity. By using rotating ring-disk electrode (RRDE) technique, the OER pathway on NiCo2S4@g-C3N4-CNT is determined as a four-electron-dominated mechanism with a high Faradaic efficiency of 98.5% (Figure S15, Supporting Information). Overall, the performance parameters of NiCo2S4@g-C3N4-CNT are comparable or even better than most of the highly efficient OER electrocatalysts reported so far, as summarized in Table S2 in the Supporting Information. Long-term catalytic durability was evaluated by accelerated degradation and galvanostatic measurements. The OER curve of NiCo2S4@g-C3N4-CNT nearly overlays the original one after continuous 1000 cyclic voltammetry (CV) cycles (Figure 2c), indicating the considerable catalytic stability. This statement is also certified by the chronopotentiometry response (inset of Figure 2c), in which the NiCo2S4@g-C3N4CNT electrode exhibits 3.9% activity decay after polarizing for 60 000 s, much lower than that of NiCo2S4@g-C3N4/CNT (12.7% after 45 000 s). After 1000 repeated OER cycles, the micro-nanostructure of NiCo2S4@g-C3N4-CNT hybrid is still preserved (Figure S16, Supporting Information). Despite the formation of amorphous oxide species,[5d,15] the possibility of the influence on the activity of investigated catalyst series can be excluded because similar phenomenon is also observed on the surface of physical NiCo2S4/g-C3N4/CNT mixture after OER cycling (Figure S17, Supporting Information).
As bifunctional oxygen catalytic performance is needed in regenerative fuel cells and rechargeable metal–air technologies, the ORR performance of synthesized catalysts was assessed in O2-saturated 0.1 m KOH. As shown in Figure 2d, NiCo2S4@g-C3N4-CNT composite exhibits superior ORR activity in terms of higher onset potential (0.87 V), higher half-wave potential (0.76 V), and larger limited current density (4.8 mA cm−2) in comparison with other benchmarks (Figure S18, Supporting Information), which also rivals with many TMC electrocatalysts reported so far (Table S3, Supporting Information). RRDE measurements further disclose an efficient quasi-4-electron oxygen reduction pathway on the surface of NiCo2S4@g-C3N4-CNT (Figure S19, Supporting Information). In the fitted Tafel profiles (Figure 2e), NiCo2S4@g-C3N4-CNT gives the smallest value of 74 mV dec−1, closely approaching that of Pt/C (69 mV dec−1), highlighting its favorable ORR kinetic. Additionally, EIS curves at 0.7 V reveal the smaller charge transfer resistance of NiCo2S4@g-C3N4CNT (Figure S14, Supporting Information), which is another key factor in enhancing its ORR capability. The doublelayer capacitances (Cdl) are determined to be 5.39, 39.8, and 41.7 mF cm−2 for NiCo2S4/g-C3N4/CNT, NiCo2S4@g-C3N4/ CNT, and NiCo2S4@g-C3N4-CNT (Figure S20, Supporting Information), respectively. The large and comparable values of the latter two hybrids evidence the coactivation of bimetallic sites by N-rich g-C3N4 in in situ fabricated NiCo2S4@g-C3N4, offering more catalytically active sites for O2 adsorption and
Adv. Mater. 2019, 1808281
© 2019 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim1808281 (5 of 10)
subsequent reactions. Notably, the coupling extent of NiCo2S4 and g-C3N4 support can be dramatically influenced by modifying the surface protonation and functional groups of g-C3N4 nanosheets (Figure S21, Supporting Information). The added amount of CNT in the NiCo2S4@g-C3N4-CNT hybrid is optimized at a moderate content (Figure S22, Supporting Information). As an ideal conductive substrate, graphene is also used to fabricate the hybrid composite (Figure S23, Supporting Information), which exhibits considerable catalytic performance, demonstrating the universality of proposed synthetic strategy. Compared to oxide-based hybrid catalyst (Figure S24, Supporting Information), the cooperation of S element in NiCo2S4 contributes to the improved intrinsic electrical conductivity and favorable binding strength,[16] facilitating the reversible oxygen electrocatalysis. In addition to the high catalytic activity, NiCo2S4@g-C3N4-CNT composite also displays remarkable ORR catalytic stability with negligible change in the CV curves after extended 6000 cycles (Figure 2f; Figure S25, Supporting Information). Aforementioned facts collectively corroborate the superior bifunctional OER/OER activity and long-term durability of NiCo2S4@g-C3N4-CNT hybrid electrode, demonstrating its promising application for reversible oxygen electrochemistry in fuel cells and metal–air batteries. A series of DFT computations was performed to elucidate the crucial role of N-rich g-C3N4 in activating bimetallic Ni/Co sites and the synergistic mechanism at the hybrid interfaces for enhancing ORR/OER activity. Differential charge density analysis reveals apparent interfacial electron transfer from
Adv. Mater. 2019, 1808281
© 2019 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim1808281 (6 of 10)
NiCo2S4 to g-C3N4 in the NiCo2S4@g-C3N4 hybrid, resulting in an electron deletion region on NiCo2S4 surface and an electron accumulation region on g-C3N4 surface (Figure S26, Supporting Information). Detailed calculated data suggests the electron cloud migration from metallic Ni and Co sites to electronegative N sites (Table S4, Supporting Information), in agreement with experimental results. Based on previous references,[5e,6g] four elementary steps are assumed in both ORR and OER; whereas the ORR proceeds through the formation of OO*, HOO*, O*, and HO* (*denotes the active site, Figures S27–S29, Supporting Information) and the OER occurs in the reverse direction. We also take into account bare NiCo2S4 and NiCo2S4 supported on N-doped graphene (NiCo2S4@N-GN, Figure S30, Supporting Information) as comparative models to identify the critical role of rich N species in g-C3N4 in affecting the ORR/OER energetics of NiCo2S4@gC3N4. All intermediates bind at a single Co site on bare NiCo2S4 surface. While on the hybrid interfaces of NiCo2S4@N-GN and NiCo2S4@g-C3N4, the OO* and HOO* prefer to coadsorb on Co and its adjacent Ni atom via a bridge configuration, referred as a dual-site mechanism (Figure 3a–d), which is beneficial for the rupture of OO bond and has been recognized to facilitate the reversible ORR/OER.[9a,12] Specifically, the involved Ni and Co active sites in NiCo2S4@g-C3N4 are connected to two pyridinicN atoms in g-C3N4 matrix, forming a Ni, Co–N2 moiety that simultaneously optimizes the electronic configuration of bimetallic atoms (Figure 3c,d). This leads to the downshift of d-band center positions (Figure 3e) and weakens the bonding strength with oxygen intermediates, rendering the bimetallic sites with high reactivity,[17] similar to the recognized Co–Nx and Ni–Nx groups in M–N/C materials.[7,18] Moreover, as confirmed by free energy diagram calculations (Figure 3f), the most negative free energy of bare NiCo2S4 suggests the strongest chemical adsorption with oxygen-containing reactants, which hinders the desorption behavior and results in the sluggish reaction kinetic. However, when anchoring on N-supported graphene or g-C3N4 nanosheet, all reaction barriers are largely reduced, especially in the case of the NiCo2S4@g-C3N4 heterostructure. For ORR catalysis, the rate-determining step (RDS) is the desorption of HO* with the limiting barrier of 0.66 eV for NiCo2S4@N-GN, whereas the smallest uphill barrier further decreases to 0.51 eV for NiCo2S4@g-C3N4 and the RDS becomes the reduction of HOO* to O*. Regarding the OER, a similar analysis of the energy simulation indicates the favorable thermodynamic/kinetic properties on NiCo2S4@g-C3N4 interfaces. The minimum potentials for the three different catalysts where all reaction steps become downhill further corroborate the OER capability trend follows the order of NiCo2S4@g-C3N4 > NiCo2S4@N-GN > NiCo2S4 (Figure S31, Supporting Information). Therefore, benefitting from the atomistic engineering of bimetallic active sites by high-level N atoms in NiCo2S4@gC3N4, the adsorption, activation and desorption features of all oxygen intermediates on Co and Ni sites are energetically facilitated, thereby optimizing the pathways and accelerating the reaction kinetics (Figure S32, Supporting Information). Furthermore, the prominent advantage of g-C3N4 support in favoring the oxygen reduction process is also demonstrated by considering another computational model of NiCo2S4 on g-C3N4 and N-GN (Figure S33, Supporting Information). Additionally, the in situ chemically coupled CNTs in the integrated
Adv. Mater. 2019, 1808281
© 2019 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim1808281 (7 of 10)
NiCo2S4@g-C3N4-CNT electrode can ensure efficient electron transfer while the well-designed free-standing architecture favors the catalytic processes by offering large surface area and rich pore structure for electrolyte infiltration and gas/ion diffusion. In summary, the excellent electrochemical performance of NiCo2S4@g-C3N4-CNT is attributed to the increased amount of activated bimetallic sites, the enhanced intrinsic reactivity of metal species, the efficient electron transfer pathway, and novel nanostructure.
The outstanding bifunctional ORR/OER properties inspire us to evaluate their application in practical ZABs. The assembled free-standing NiCo2S4@g-C3N4-CNT films can be directly employed as air cathodes for rechargeable ZABs without additional manufacturing (Figure 4a). The alkaline ZABs catalyzed by NiCo2S4@g-C3N4-CNT exhibit a stable open circuit of ≈1.45 V (Figure 4b), higher than those of NiCo2S4@g-C3N4/ CNT (1.35 V), NiCo2S4/g-C3N4/CNT (1.27 V), and Pt/C+RuO2 (1.38 V), sharing the same sequence to that observed in the three-electrode configuration. A light emitting diode (LED) screen can be powered by three ZABs connected in series (Figure 4c). The cell based on NiCo2S4@g-C3N4-CNT achieves a peak power density of 142 mW cm−2, achieving 87.1% of that using Pt/C+RuO2 catalyst (163 mW cm−2, Figure 4d). Moreover, the discharge plateau of NiCo2S4@g-C3N4-CNT cathode decreases by only 0.11 from 1.32 V at 3 mA cm−2 to 1.21 V at 20 mA cm−2 (Figure 4e), which is the lowest among investigated electrodes, signaling its considerable rate capability. Meanwhile, the discharge voltage for NiCo2S4@g-C3N4-CNT is the highest among all current densities, again evidencing its superior ORR activity. When assembled in a primary battery, NiCo2S4@g-C3N4-CNT cathode gives large discharge capacities of 485.7 and 493.0 mAh g–1 Zn at 10 and 20 mA cm−2 on the basis of consumed Zn weight (Figure 4f). The impedance measurements at 1.2 V reveal the smallest charge transfer resistance for NiCo2S4@g-C3N4-CNT (Figure 4g), indicating its advantage in facilitating battery kinetics. Moreover, the NiCo2S4@g-C3N4-CNT enables rechargeable ZABs with superior rechargeability, delivering stable discharge-recharge cycle behaviors (Figure 4h). The initial discharge and charge overpotential of NiCo2S4@gC3N4-CNT-based ZABs is 0.84 V at 10 mA cm–2 with a high round-trip efficiency of 60.6%, outperforming that of noble metal Pt/C+RuO2 (0.92 V, 57.2%, Figure S34, Supporting Information). Negligible performance fading is observed after operation for 330 cycles (110 h) for the NiCo2S4@g-C3N4-CNT electrode whereas the voltage gap sharply increases to 1.41 V after 58 cycles for Pt/C+RuO2 catalyst. These battery parameters
Adv. Mater. 2019, 1808281
© 2019 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim1808281 (8 of 10)
are comparable to the most active noble metal free materials (Table S5), highlighting the synthesized integrated hybrid catalysts as inexpensive and high-performance electrode materials for driving electrochemical metal–air technologies.
Inspired by the growing demand for portable and flexible electronic devices, all-solid-state ZABs were fabricated using the prepared NiCo2S4@g-C3N4-CNT hybrid film cathode and poly(vinyl alcohol) (PVA)-KOH electrolyte (Figure 5a). The solidstate ZABs display remarkably stable open-circuit potential at different bending angles (Figure 5b,c; Figure S35, Supporting Information), suggesting the considerable flexibility. The batteries under 90° and 180° bending angles deliver similar discharge platforms to that in a flat state at various current densities (Figure 5d). The remarkable flexibility of our batteries at different bending states is mainly ascribed to the highly flexible feature of NiCo2S4@g-C3N4-CNT integrated film. Compared to the other two counterparts, NiCo2S4@g-C3N4-CNT promotes solid-state ZABs with a higher specific discharge capacity of 480.7 mAh g–1 Zn (Figure 5e), corresponding to an energy density of 530.5 Wh kg–1 Zn. This value even rivals that in liquid ZABs, highlighting the promising application of this material for future flexible and wearable electronics. Moreover, NiCo2S4@g-C3N4-CNT also endows assembled rechargeable solid-state ZABs with stable discharge/charge cycling performance for more than 14 h (42 cycles, Figure 5f), implying superior rechargeability. As examples of real devices, solid-state ZABs connected in series are capable of powering an electronic watch and an LED screen for more than four hours and can work well throughout the entire bending process (Figure 5g,h; Video S1, Supporting Information). Moreover, a self-driven water splitting system using two portable ZABs in series was fabricated to explore the practicability for alkaline water splitting (Figure 5i). Obvious O2 and H2 bubbles can be observed on the electrode surface. The quantified ratios of generated O2 and H2 in experiments being close to two coincide with theoretically calculated values (Figure S36, Supporting Information), indicative of near 100% Faradaic efficiency. Regarding these observations, the integrated NiCo2S4@g-C3N4-CNT hybrid
Adv. Mater. 2019, 1808281
© 2019 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim1808281 (9 of 10)
demonstrates considerable electrochemical performance as reversible oxygen electrodes in both liquid and solid-state ZABs.
In summary, aiming at identifying the synergistic effect of bimetallic active sites for oxygen electrocatalysis, we presented the controlled synthesis of a novel free-standing NiCo2S4@g-C3N4-CNT nanocomposite and the systematic investigation of using it as the bifunctional catalyst for catalyzing ORR/OER and ZABs. Electron donation from bimetallic Ni and Co atoms in NiCo2S4 to pyridinic-N dopants in g-C3N4 and efficient charge transfer property provided by in situ coupled conductive CNTs were experimentally demonstrated to contribute to the enhanced bifunctional activities. Theoretical simulation identifies the new mechanism of abundant pyridinic-N species in coactivating bimetallic Ni and Co active sites through a Ni, Co–N2 moiety center, which simultaneously downshifts their d-band center and energetically facilitates the reactions of oxygen-containing reactants, consequently promoting the reversible oxygen electrocatalysis. The resultant nanocomposite delivers remarkable bifunctional activity and stability in alkaline medium and excellent discharge/charge behaviors in real ZABs, superior to transitionmetal and noble-metal electrocatalysts. This work will provide deeper understanding on the catalytic mechanism of bimetallic sites and also shed light on the rational design of efficient and durable hybrid nanocatalysts through interfacial regulation for diverse applications in renewable energy storage and conversion technologies.
